Pre-Game Insights: Experts favored the Celtics to win based on their recent performance.
The Celtics remain 2nd in the East, 4.5 games behind the first place Cleveland Cavaliers, who have won their last 8 games.
The Thunder are in first place in the West. They are 6.5 games ahead of 2nd place Memphis and 7 ahead of 3rd place Houston.
This is the third game of a 4 game Western road trip for the Celtics.
Kristaps Porzingis should be ready to play after missing 4 straight games with a sprained ankle.
Al Horford is expected to return for this game.
Jalen Brown is questionable for this game due to a shoulder strain.
Alex Caruso will miss his 7th game with a hip strain for the Thunder.
Cason Wallace will likely continue to start in place of Alex Caruso.
Chet Holmgren is out with a right iliac hip fracture.
Isaiah Hartenstein will continue to start in place of Chet Holmgren.
Defense is always a key to winning. The Thunder average 115.4 points per game (10th) and the Celtics average 119.4 points per game (4th).

Rebounding is also a key to winning. The Celtics need to rebound on both ends of the court to keep the Thunder from getting second chance points and they need to rebound on the offensive end to give themselves extra possessions.
Taking care of the ball is essential. The Thunder are 1st in the league with 23.4 points off turnovers per game and 1st with 11.8 steals per game.
The Thunder have not lost to an Eastern Conference team this season and have only lost 5 games.
The Celtics need to overcome the distractions of travel and playing on the road in front of hostile fans.
Coaching may be a factor in this game, as both Joe Mazzulla and Mark Daigneault have had successful seasons.
Officiating can be an x-factor in the game, as it can significantly impact the outcome.
